creator: allane3sexton@netscape.net
text:
When starting Tomcat 4.0 b5 on Win98, the classpath that is used is:

Using CLASSPATH: D:\tomcat\bin\bootstrap.jar;D:\jdk1.3\lib\tools.jar

It did not pick up the classpath I have set on my PC.  The effect of that is I 
am not able to import any of my classes in my jsp files.  

To fix this I modified the script, Catalina.bat, found in %CATALINA_HOME%/bin.
I changed this portion of the script:

rem ----- Set Up The Runtime Classpath ----------------------------------------

set CP=%CATALINA_HOME%\bin\bootstrap.jar;%JAVA_HOME%\lib\tools.jar
set CLASSPATH=%CP%
echo Using CLASSPATH: %CLASSPATH%

To this:

rem ----- Set Up The Runtime Classpath ----------------------------------------

set CP=%CATALINA_HOME%\bin\bootstrap.jar;%JAVA_HOME%\lib\tools.jar
set CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;%CP%
echo Using CLASSPATH: %CLASSPATH% 

Thanks,
Allane

Not picking up the existing CLASSPATH is a deliberate choice, and will not be
changed.  CLASSPATH problems cause the *vast* majority of user errors when
installing and running Tomcat.  In particular, Windows has severe limits on the
length (and legal characters) in environment variables that cause even more
problems here.

If you wish to make application classes available to all web applications, you
can put them (unpacked) under $CATALINA_HOME/classes or in JAR files under
$CATALINA_HOME/lib.  All such classes are automatically made visible to all web
applications (without any need to modify environment variables).
